Table <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The data show the growth of haploid Saccharomyces cerevisiae yeast strains on media that differ in amino acid content. A plus sign (<math alttext="plus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>) indicates that the yeast strains grow, and a minus sign (<math alttext="minus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>) indicates that the strains do not grow.

The yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae is a single-celled organism. Amino acid synthesis in yeast cells occurs through metabolic pathways, and enzymes in the synthesis pathways are encoded by different genes. The synthesis of a particular amino acid can be prevented by mutation of a gene encoding an enzyme in the required pathway.

A researcher conducted an experiment to determine the ability of yeast to grow on media that differ in amino acid content. Yeast can grow as both haploid and diploid cells. The researcher tested two different haploid yeast strains (Mutant <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and Mutant <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>), each of which has a single recessive mutation, and a haploid wild-type strain. The resulting data are shown in Table <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Identify the role of treatment <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> in the experiment.

Table <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The data show the growth of haploid Saccharomyces cerevisiae yeast strains on media that differ in amino acid content. A plus sign (<math alttext="plus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>) indicates that the yeast strains grow, and a minus sign (<math alttext="minus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>) indicates that the strains do not grow.

The yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae is a single-celled organism. Amino acid synthesis in yeast cells occurs through metabolic pathways, and enzymes in the synthesis pathways are encoded by different genes. The synthesis of a particular amino acid can be prevented by mutation of a gene encoding an enzyme in the required pathway.

A researcher conducted an experiment to determine the ability of yeast to grow on media that differ in amino acid content. Yeast can grow as both haploid and diploid cells. The researcher tested two different haploid yeast strains (Mutant <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and Mutant <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>), each of which has a single recessive mutation, and a haploid wild-type strain. The resulting data are shown in Table <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Identify the role of treatment <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> in the experiment.

(b) Provide reasoning to explain how Mutant <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> can grow on treatment <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> medium but cannot grow on treatment <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> medium.

(c) Yeast mate by fusing two haploid cells to make a diploid cell. In a second experiment, the researcher mates the Mutant <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and Mutant <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> haploid strains to produce diploid cells. Using the table provided, predict whether the diploid cells will grow on each of the four media. Use a plus sign (<math alttext="plus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>) to indicate growth and a minus sign (<math alttext="minus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>) to indicate no growth.

skill.text: 3.C: Identify experimental procedures that align with the question, including: i. identifying dependent and independent variables ii. identifying appropriate controls iii. justifying appropriate controls
